shortDescription: Reduce the hours alcohol can be sold in my community
longDescription: New Zealand adults who support reducing the hours when alcohol can be sold in the community where they live.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you would support or oppose the following changes, if they were made to help reduce the problems associated with alcohol use.
questions.question: Reducing the hours when alcohol can be sold in my community where I live.

shortDescription: Increase restrictions on advertising/promotion seen or heard by under 18s
longDescription: New Zealand adults who support increasing the restrictions on alcohol advertising or promotion that is seen or heard by people under 18.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you would support or oppose the following changes, if they were made to help reduce the problems associated with alcohol use.
questions.question: Increasing the restrictions on alcohol advertising or promotion that is seen or heard by people under 18 years of age.

shortDescription: Ban alcohol-related sponsorship of events that people under 18 may attend
longDescription: New Zealand adults who support banning alcohol related sponsorship of events that people under the age of 18 may attend.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you would support or oppose the following changes, if they were made to help reduce the problems associated with alcohol use.
questions.question: Banning alcohol-related sponsorship of events that people under the age of 18 may attend.

shortDescription: Too many local places to buy alcohol
longDescription: New Zealand adults who think the number of places where alcohol can be bought in their local areas is too many.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you would support or oppose the following changes, if they were made to help reduce the problems associated with alcohol use.
questions.question: Do you think the number of places where alcohol can be bought in your local area is too few, about right, or too many?

shortDescription: New Zealand adults whose main meal of the day was prepared at home 5+ days in the last week.
longDescription: The main meal is the largest meal of the day. A meal prepared at home could include a meal that has been added to with takeaways like rice or hot chips.

questions.question: Thinking about the last 7 days, that is from last [7 days ago] until yesterday, on how many of those days was your main meal prepared at home?

shortDescription: New Zealand adults whose main meal of the day was bought outside home 3+ days in the last week.
longDescription: The main meal is the largest meal of the day. Bought outside the home means meals bought at a takeaway outlet, restaurant, food court, café, pub, petrol station or dairy.

questions.question: Over the last 7 days, on how many days was your entire main meal bought outside the home, such as buying takeaways, or eating at a restaurant?

longDescription: All or most members of the household eat the main meal of the day together always or frequently.

questions.question: How often do all, or most, of the members of your household eat the main meal of the day together?

longDescription: All or most members of the household eat the main meal of the day together sometimes.

questions.question: How often do all, or most, of the members of your household eat the main meal of the day together?

longDescription: All or most members of the household eat the main meal of the day together almost never or never.

questions.question: How often do all, or most, of the members of your household eat the main meal of the day together?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who participated in any gambling activities in the last 12 months.
longHidden:
Gambling activities include placing a bet with the NZ TAB on a horse or dog race or a sporting event, buying any NZ Lotteries Commission (Lotto) products, playing on gaming (pokie) machines in a pub, club or casino, playing table games at one of the six casinos, playing housie or bingo, playing an internet game to win money, buying a raffle ticket, participating for money in sweepstakes with friends, family or workmates, making bets for money with friends or family, placing a bet or buying tickets through an overseas online website.

Questions are about participation in different gambling activities either online, at home, or elsewhere. Respondents who answered yes to any of these questions are defined as gamblers.

questions.question: I’ll read out different types of gambling that are available. Include gambling at home and elsewhere. For each type, please tell me whether or not you have done that activity in the last 12 months.
options: Placed a bet on a horse or dog race with the New Zealand TAB.
Placed a bet on any other sports event with the New Zealand TAB.
Bought an Instant Kiwi or scratch ticket.
Bought a Lotto, Strike, Powerball (Wednesday or Saturday) ticket.
Bought a Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 ticket.
Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club.
Played gaming machines, or pokies, at one of the six casinos.
Played table games, such as card games or dice, at one of the six casinos.
Played Housie or Bingo for money.
Played an Internet game to win money.
Bought a raffle ticket or attended a casino fundraising evening.
Participated in sweepstakes for money with your work mates, friends or family on such things as the Melbourne Cup.
Made bets for money with family or friends, on such things as card games.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you spent or bet any money, bought any tickets or paid to do any of the activities listed on online through a website or mobile phone for money or prizes?
options: Horse or dog race online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account]
Sports event online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account]
Event bet through a website (for example, an election result or TV show)
Online poker/Other online casino games such as blackjack, roulette, etc.
Online pokies/Internet bingo/Skill games online such as chess, scrabble, mah-jong, bridge, backgammon, etc.
Overseas lottery, lotto or keno ticket online [NOT through a NZ MyLotto account]
Fantasy or novelty betting such as virtual sports or other events
Any other gambling or lottery activity online through a website for money (for example, online gaming machines or instant games)

longDescription: New Zealand adults who played on gaming machines (pokies) in pub, club or one of the six casinos in last 12 months.
longHidden: Respondents answered Yes to at least one of the gaming machinesāpokies questions.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club.

Played gaming machines, or pokies, at one of the six casinos.
i: The six casinos are in Auckland, Hamilton, Christchurch, Dunedin, and two in Queenstown

longDescription: New Zealand adults who bought any NZ Lotteries Commission (Lotto) products in last 12 months.
longHidden: Lotto products are Instant Kiwi ticket/s (scratchies), online Instant Play ticket/s (online scratchies), Lotto, Strike, Powerball, Big Wednesday (2014, 2012 HLS), Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 tickets.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Bought an Instant Kiwi, Instant Play or scratch ticket (scratchie)?
Bought a Lotto, Strike, Powerball (Wednesday or Saturday) ticket.
Bought a Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 ticket.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who participated in online gambling on overseas websites in the last 12 months.
longHidden: This indicator reports on respondents who answered Yes to any of the activities.

questions.leadIn: In the last 12 months, have you bet any money, bought any tickets or paid to do any of the listed activities online through a website or mobile phone for money or prizes?
questions.question: i: Do not include placing a bet through a NZ TAB account, buying a ticket through a NZ MyLotto account, spending money to download games on to your PC, purchasing game software, or doing any of the activities for free.
options: Betting:
Horse or dog race online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account].
Sports event online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account].
Event bet through a website (for example, an election result or TV show).
Poker/Casino games/Pokies:
Online poker.
Other online casino games such as blackjack, roulette etc.
Online pokies.
Other:
Internet bingo.
Skill games online such as chess, scrabble, mah-jong, bridge, backgammon, etc.
Overseas lottery, lotto or keno ticket online [NOT through a NZ MyLotto account].
Fantasy/novelty betting such as virtual sports or other events.
Any other gambling or lottery activity online through a website for money (for example, online gaming machines or instant games).

longDescription: New Zealand adults who placed a bet on a horse or dog race or on a sporting event with the New Zealand TAB in the last 12 months.
longHidden: Respondents who answered Yes to either Question.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Placed a bet on a horse or dog race with the New Zealand TAB.
Placed a bet on any other sports event with the New Zealand TAB.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who bought NZ Lotteries Commission (Lotto) products at least once a week in the last 12 months.
longHidden:
Lotto products are Instant Kiwi ticket/s (scratchies), online Instant Play ticket/s (online scratchies), Lotto, Strike, Powerball, Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 tickets.

Questions are about participation in different gambling activities. Respondents who answered yes to any of these Questions are then asked about the frequency of their participation.

questions.question: In the last 12 months have you...
options: Bought an Instant Kiwi, Instant Play or scratch ticket (scratchie)?
Bought a Lotto, Strike, Powerball (Wednesday or Saturday) ticket.
Bought a Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 ticket.

questions.question: Please tell me about how often you do that.
answers: Less than once every three months

shortDescription: Gaming machines in pub/club - at least weekly
longDescription: New Zealand adults who played gaming machines or pokies in a pub or club at least once a week in the last 12 months.

questions.leadIn: In the last 12 months, have you...
questions.question: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club?

questions.leadIn: Please tell me about how often you do that.
questions.question: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club?
answers: Less than once every three months

shortDescription: Horse/dog races/sports events - at least monthly
longDescription: New Zealand adults who bet on horse/dog races or sports events through the New Zealand TAB at least once a month.
longHidden: Respondents who answered yes to TAB gambling participation questions are then asked about the frequency of their participation.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Placed a bet on a horse or dog race with the New Zealand TAB.
Placed a bet on any other sports event with the New Zealand TAB.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me about how often you do that.
questions.question: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club?
answers: Less than once every three months

shortDescription: Continuous forms of gambling - at least weekly
longDescription: New Zealand adults who participated at least once a week in continuous forms of gambling in past 12 months.
longHidden: Continuous gambling is where winnings can be immediately 'reinvested'. Betting on races or sports events, playing gaming or pokie machines or playing table games at casinos and housie are examples of continuous forms of gambling.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Placed a bet on a horse or dog race with the New Zealand TAB.
Placed a bet on any other sports event with the New Zealand TAB.
Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club.
Played gaming machines, or pokies, at one of the six casinos.
Played table games, such as card games or dice, at one of the six casinos.
Played Housie or Bingo for money.
Played an Internet game to win money.

questions.question: Please tell me about how often you do that.
answers: Less than once every three months

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you bet any money, bought any tickets or paid to do any of the listed activities online through a website or mobile phone for money or prizes?
options: Horse or dog race online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account]
Sports event online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account].

questions.question: About how often have you placed a bet on a horse or dog race online through an overseas TAB, bookie or betting exchange [NOT through a NZ TAB account]?
answers: Less than once every three months

shortDescription: Non continuous forms of gambling - at least weekly
longDescription: New Zealand adults who participated at least once a week in non-continuous forms of gambling in the last 12 months.
longHidden: Buying lottery tickets, going to casino evenings/buying raffle tickets for fundraising are examples of non-continuous forms of gambling.

questions.question: In the last 12 months, have you...
options: Bought an Instant Kiwi or scratch ticket
Bought a Lotto, Strike, Powerball (Wednesday or Saturday) ticket.
Bought a Keno, Bullseye or Play 3 ticket.
Bought a raffle ticket or attended a casino fundraising evening.
Participated in sweepstakes for money with your work mates, friends or family on such things as the Melbourne Cup.
Made bets for money with family or friends, on such things as card games.

questions.question: Please tell me about how often you do that.
answers: Less than once every three months

longDescription: New Zealand adults who participated in 4 or more gambling activities in the past 12 months.
longHidden: This indicator reports on participation in 4 or more different gambling activities. For example, if a respondent said they bought an Instant Kiwi ticket and played Pokies at a pub/club they would have participated in two gambling activities and therefore will not be included in this indicator. Note that over time more kinds of gambling activities have become available, also as activities become more common, they are more likely to be asked about in a separate question in the HLS.

longDescription: Average number of gambling activities participated in past 12 months.
longHidden: This is the sum of different gambling activities. For example, if a respondent said they bought an Instant Kiwi ticket and played Pokies at a pub/club they participated in two gambling activities. Note that over time more kinds of gambling activities have become available; also as activities become more common, they are more likely to be asked about in a separate question in the HLS.

longDescription: Individual gambling harm (PGSI): non-problem gamblers.
longHidden:
Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI; Ferris & Wynne, 2001) is a 9-item scale used to assess people’s experiences of gambling-related harm in the last 12 months.

An example item is: “Thinking about the last 12 months, how often have you bet more than you could really afford to lose?” Participants rated themselves on a 4-point scale from 0 (never) to 3 (almost always). Response values from each participant were added to calculate the total score and ‘refused’ or ‘don’t know’ was coded as ‘never’ (0). Possible scores range from 0 to 27 with higher scores being indicative of greater problem of gambling. Non-problem gamblers had a score of zero.

longDescription: Individual gambling harm (PGSI): Low risk gamblers.
longHidden:
Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI; Ferris & Wynne, 2001) is a 9-item scale used to assess people’s experiences of gambling-related harm in the last 12 months.

An example item is: “Thinking about the last 12 months, how often have you bet more than you could really afford to lose?” Participants rated themselves on a 4-point scale from 0 (never) to 3 (almost always). Response values from each participant were added to calculate the total score and ‘refused’ or ‘don’t know’ was coded as ‘never’ (0). Possible scores range from 0 to 27 with higher scores being indicative of greater problem of gambling. Low risk gamblers have a score of 1-2.

longDescription: Individual gambling harm (PGSI): Moderate risk and problem gamblers.
longHidden:
Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI; Ferris & Wynne, 2001) is a 9-item scale used to assess people’s experiences of gambling-related harm in the last 12 months.

An example item is: “Thinking about the last 12 months, how often have you bet more than you could really afford to lose?” Participants rated themselves on a 4-point scale from 0 (never) to 3 (almost always).

Response values from each participant were added to calculate the total score and ‘refused’ or ‘don’t know’ was coded as ‘never’ (0). Possible scores range from 0 to 27 with higher scores being indicative of greater problem of gambling. Because the number of respondents who were classified as ‘problem gamblers’ (n = 19) was too small to be analysed separately, ‘moderate-risk’ and ‘problem gamblers’ were combined into one group, as in the Gambling report: Results from the 2016 Health and Lifestyles Survey. Moderate risk gamblers have a score of 3-7 and Problem gamblers have a score of 8-27. This combined group can be described as experienced some level of gambling harm.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who gambled and had an occasion when they spent more time or money gambling than intended to, in the last 12 months.

questions.question: Over the last 12 months, have you had a day, or an outing, where at the end of it you looked back and thought to yourself – I really overdid that? I spent more time or money gambling than I meant to.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who experienced at least one form of household-level gambling harm in last 12 months (an argument or going without due to gambling).

questions.question: Some argument about time or money spend on betting or gambling.
And has this happened in the last 12 months?
Someone had to go without something they needed, or some bills weren't paid, because too much was spent on gambling by another person.
And has this happened in the last 12 months?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who experienced a friend or family member spending more time or money on gambling than they intended to, in the last 12 months.

questions.question: Over the last 12 months, do you feel that someone close to you has had a day or an occasion where they spent much more time or money than they meant to, on gambling? This can be a friend, family member, or partner. You don't need to say who.

shortDescription: Pokies in pubs/clubs are more harmful than other gambling activities
longDescription: New Zealand adults who think that gaming machines (pokies) in pubs or clubs are potentially more harmful than other gambling activities.

questions.question: Do you think that any of these types of gambling or games are more likely than others to attract people into playing more often, or for more money than they should?
Which are the most likely to do so?
answers: Gaming machines or pokies at a pub or club

shortDescription: Know what to do to help a friend or family member
longDescription: New Zealand adults who know what to do to help a friend or family member who gambles too much.

questions.question: Do you know what you could do to help a friend or family member who gambles too much?

shortDescription: Concern with the level of gambling in the community
longDescription: New Zealand adults who had some degree of concern with the level of gambling in the community.

questions.question: How concerned are you about the level of gambling in your community?

shortDescription: Spent more than $25 on playing gaming machines/pokies
longDescription: Spent more than $25 on an average session playing gaming machines or pokies at a pub, club or casino.

questions.question: On average, how much do you spend in a session playing the pokies?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who played gaming machines or pokies at either a pubs or club.

questions.leadIn: In the last 12 months, have you...
questions.question: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at a pub or club.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who played gambling machines or pokies at one of the six casinos. The six casinos are in Auckland, Hamilton, Christchurch, Dunedin, and two in Queenstown.

questions.leadIn: In the last 12 months, have you...
questions.question: Played gaming machines, or pokies, at one of the six casinos.

shortDescription: Important to maintain a strong connection to culture
longDescription: New Zealand adults who agree or strongly agree that maintaining a strong connection to their culture is important to them.

questions.question: Maintaining a strong connection to my culture is important to me.

longDescription: Felt isolated from others at any time over the last 4 weeks. This includes those who felt isolated only a little of the time through to those who felt isolated all of the time.

questions.question: In the last four weeks, how often have you felt isolated from others?

shortDescription: Ever diagnosed with a mental illness
longDescription: Has ever been diagnosed with a mental illness.

questions.question: Have you ever been diagnosed with a mental illness?

shortDescription: Treated unfairly because of a mental illness - in general
longDescription: New Zealand adults with a diagnosed mental illness who report being treated unfairly or discriminated against because of their experience of mental illness.
longHidden: This indicator is derived from the following questions.

questions.question: Have you ever been diagnosed with a mental illness?

questions.leadIn: Those who answered 'Yes' to the question are asked:
questions.question: Have you ever been treated unfairly or believe you have been discriminated against because of your experience of mental illness?

shortDescription: Discrimination setting for those who have been treated unfairly because of a mental illness - workplace
longDescription: New Zealand adults with a diagnosed mental illness who report being treated unfairly or discriminated against in the workplace.
longHidden: This indicator is derived from the following questions.

questions.question: Have you ever been diagnosed with a mental illness?

questions.leadIn: For those who answered 'Yes' the following question was asked:
questions.question: Have you ever been treated unfairly or believe you have been discriminated against because of your experience of mental illness?

questions.leadIn: For those who answered 'Yes' the following question was asked:
questions.question: Please, can you identify the settings where you were treated unfairly or were discriminated against. Response 1: Workplace.

shortDescription: Tell employer if diagnosed with a mental illness
longDescription: New Zealand adults who would tell their employer if they were diagnosed with a mental illness.

questions.question: If you were diagnosed with a mental illness, who would you tell? Response 5: Your employer.

shortDescription: Know someone who has experienced a mental illness
longDescription: New Zealand adults who have had someone they know tell them they have experienced mental illness.

questions.question: Has anyone you know ever told you that they have experienced mental illness?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who got sunburnt (with blisters or were in pain for 2+ days) last spring/summer (September to February).

questions.question:
The next question is about the last New Zealand spring and summer. By this I mean September [previous year] to February [current year].
 During that time, how many times did you get sunburnt, where you got blisters or were in pain for two or more days?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who got sunburnt (with reddening or soreness of the skin) after being in the sun last spring/summer (September to February). This does not include those times where they were badly sunburnt.

questions.question:
The next question is about the last New Zealand spring and summer. By this I mean September [previous year] to February [current year]. 
Over that same time, how many times did you get sunburnt, where you had reddening or soreness of the skin after being in the sun? 
Do not include the times you got blisters or were in pain for two or more days.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who used sunscreen to protect themselves from getting sunburnt.

questions.question: What are the things you do, if anything, to protect yourself from getting sunburnt?
options: Cover up with clothing.
Wear a hat.
Wear sunglasses.
Wear a rash shirt.
Wear sunscreen.
Reapply sunscreen regularly.
Reapply sunscreen at least every two hours.
Seek shade/Stay in the shade/Stay out of the sun.

shortDescription: Skin check in the last 2 years
longDescription: New Zealand adults who had a skin check from a doctor in the last two years.
longHidden: A skin check is where a health professional checks the skin on the whole body, as well as any unusual looking spots, freckles or moles.

questions.question: In the past two years, have you had a skin check from a health professional? This is where a health professional checks the skin on your whole body, as well as any unusual looking spots, freckles or moles.
answers: Yes - Doctor (GP), Skin doctor (Dermatologist), Specialist, Nurse, Other – (please specify)

shortDescription: Ban smoking in cars when children under 18 years old are present
longDescription: New Zealand adults who agree or strongly agree that smoking in cars should be banned when children under 18 years old are present.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions.question: Smoking in cars should be banned when children aged under 18 years old are in them.

shortDescription: Banning smoking in all public outdoor dining areas
longDescription: New Zealand adults who agree or strongly agree that smoking should be banned in all public outdoor dining areas.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions.question: Smoking in cars should be banned when children aged under 18 years old are in them.

shortDescription: Reduce number of places allowed to sell cigarettes and tobacco
longDescription: New Zealand adults who agree or strongly agree that the number of places allowed to sell cigarettes and tobacco should be reduced to make them less easily available.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions.question: Smoking in cars should be banned when children aged under 18 years old are in them.

shortDescription: Increase price to decrease affordability for young people
longDescription: New Zealand adults who agree or strongly agree that cigarettes and tobacco should be made more expensive so that young people can’t afford to buy them.

questions.leadIn: Please tell me how much you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions.question: Smoking in cars should be banned when children aged under 18 years old are in them.

shortDescription: Perceived proportion of smokers in NZ
longDescription: Perceived proportion of New Zealanders who smoke.

questions.question: Now I am going to ask a question about how many people you think smoke. Out of 100 adults in New Zealand, how many do you think smoke cigarettes or tobacco? By this we mean they smoke cigarettes or tobacco at least once a day.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who are aware that the government wants New Zealand smoking rates reduced to less than 5% by 2025. This is called "Smokefree 2025".

questions.question: Are you aware that the government wants New Zealand smoking rates reduced to less than 5% by 2025?

longDescription: No quit attempts in past 12 months. This is reported for current smokers and those who quit in the last 12 months (recent quitters).

questions.question: In the last 12 months, how many serious attempts to stop smoking did you make that lasted 24 hours or longer? Please include any attempt that you are currently making.

longDescription: One quit attempt in past 12 months. This is reported for current smokers and those who quit in the last 12 months (recent quitters).

questions.question: In the last 12 months, how many serious attempts to stop smoking did you make that lasted 24 hours or longer? Please include any attempt that you are currently making.

longDescription: Two or more quit attempts in past 12 months. This is reported for current smokers and those who quit in the last 12 months (recent quitters).

questions.question: In the last 12 months, how many serious attempts to stop smoking did you make that lasted 24 hours or longer? Please include any attempt that you are currently making.

longDescription: New Zealand adults who ever smoked tobacco, even just a few puffs.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?

longDescription: Age in years of first trying a cigarette.

questions.question: At what age did you FIRST try a cigarette, even just a few puffs?

longDescription: Age in years of starting smoking daily.

questions.question: At what age did you first start smoking daily?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who currently smoke tobacco at least monthly.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?
Which best describes how often you smoke tobacco now?
answers: Less often than once a month

longDescription: New Zealand adults who tried smoking cigarettes or tobacco, but never started smoking.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?
Which best describes how often you smoke tobacco now?
answers: Less often than once a month

questions.question: How long ago did you stop smoking?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who stopped smoking.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?
Which best describes how often you smoke tobacco now?
answers: Less often than once a month

questions.question: How long ago did you stop smoking?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who never smoked, even just a few puffs.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?

shortDescription: Average number of cigarettes smoked per day
longDescription: Average number of cigarettes smoked per day.

questions.question: How many cigarettes a day do you smoke?

longDescription: Smokers who have their first cigarette within 30 minutes of waking.

questions.question: How soon after you wake up do you smoke your first cigarette?

longDescription: New Zealand adults who smoke tobacco at least once a day.

questions.question: Have you ever smoked cigarettes or tobacco at all, even just a few puffs?
Which best describes how often you smoke tobacco now?
answers: Less often than once a month

longDescription: New Zealand adults who have smoked cannabis (marijuana, pot, grass, weed), even just a few puffs, in the last 30 days. The interviewer did not see survey participant's response.

questions.question: During the last 30 days, have you smoked marijuana (cannabis, pot, grass, weed), even just a few puffs?
answers: No – I have never smoked marijuana
No – But I have smoked marijuana in the past
Yes – Once in the past 30 days
Yes – Two or three times in the past 30 days

longDescription: New Zealand adults who have ever tried a vaping device/e-cigarette.

questions.question: Have you ever tried an e-cigarette or vaping device?

shortDescription: Current vaping product users in the population
longDescription: New Zealand adults who are current (at least monthly) vaping product users in the population.

questions.question: Which of the options on the showcard, best describes how often you use an e-cigarette or vaping device now?
answers: Less often than once a month

shortDescription: Use at least daily (of those who have tried vaping)
longDescription: Use vaping products at least daily out of those who have ever tried vaping.

questions.question: Which of the options on the showcard, best describes how often you use an e-cigarette or vaping device now?
answers: Less often than once a month

shortDescription: Use at least once a week (of those who have tried vaping
longDescription: Use vaping products at least once a week out of those who have ever tried vaping.

questions.question: Which of the options on the showcard, best describes how often you use an e-cigarette or vaping device now?
answers: Less often than once a month

shortDescription: Use vaping/e-cigarettes to stop smoking completely (only current users)
longDescription: Using vaping producs to stop smoking completely. Only asked of those who vape at least monthly.

questions.question: What is your main reason for using an e-cigarette or vaping device?
answers: To use when I cannot or am not allowed to smoke

shortDescription: Use vaping/e-cigarettes to reduce the amount of tobacco smoked (only those who currently use)
longDescription: Using vaping products to reduce the amount of tobacco smoked. Only asked of those who vape at least monthly.

questions.question: What is your main reason for using an e-cigarette or vaping device?
answers: To use when I cannot or am not allowed to smoke

shortDescription: Agree that e-cigarettes are safer than tobacco
longDescription: Perceived safety of vaping products compared with tobacco (agree/strongly agree). The statement was "E-cigarettes or vaping devices are safer for your health than smoking cigarettes." Respondents could also answer disagree, strongly disagree, or don’t know.

questions.question: E-cigarettes are safer for your health than smoked cigarettes.
answers: Not applicable – don’t know what an e-cigarette is

shortDescription: Agree that vaping helps people quit smoking
longDescription: Perceived efficacy of vaping products as a way to quit smoking (agree/strongly agree). The statement was "E-cigarettes or vaping devices can help people quit smoking tobacco." Respondents could also answer disagree, strongly disagree, or don’t know.

questions.question: E-cigarettes can help people quit smoking tobacco.
answers: Not applicable – don’t know what an e-cigarette is
